conclusion: Let m_A , m_B … masses of blocks A and B; N … normal force between A and B; f₁ … friction force on the contact A–B (coefficient μ₁); f₂ … friction force between A and the ground (coefficient μ₂)
Block B is pressed horizontally by an external force.

premise: Block B is pressed horizontally by an external force.
conclusion: Horizontally: the force F that pushes B is balanced by N (no horizontal acceleration), so the horizontal forces on B give F = N.

premise: Block B is on the point of sliding downward.
conclusion: Vertically: the upward static-friction force equals its weight: f₁ = μ₁ N = m_B g
Block A is just about to slip on the ground.

premise: Block A is just about to slip on the ground.
conclusion: Vertically: the only forces are its weight and the ground’s normal reaction, so the normal reaction from the ground is R = m_A g.

premise: Block A is just about to slip on the ground.
conclusion: Horizontally: the rightward push from B (N) is balanced by the leftward limiting static friction on A from the ground, f₂ = μ₂ R = μ₂ m_A g: N = μ₂ m_A g

premise: μ₁ N = m_B g and N = μ₂ m_A g
conclusion: Eliminate N between (1) and (2): μ₁ μ₂ m_A g = m_B g

premise: μ₁ μ₂ m_A g = m_B g
